summary_points.title: Benchmarks Rally as GDP Beats Estimates and Court Curbs Tariffs
summary_points.summary: Indian benchmarks opened sharply higher on Monday, driven by surprisingly strong 7.8% growth in the June quarter and a split U.S. appeals court ruling that declared most of President Trump’s tariffs illegal—albeit effective until mid-October. The BSE Sensex jumped over 330 points to 80,143.59, and the Nifty 50 climbed 84.45 points to 24,511.30, as investors balanced optimism over domestic resilience with lingering global trade tensions.

summary_points.title: Trump’s Tariffs Keep Sentiment Under Pressure
summary_points.summary: Despite supportive domestic data, the Indian market faced headwinds for a third consecutive session last week as uncertainty over U.S. trade policy persisted. Concerns over 50% levies on Indian exports and the ongoing saga of tariff negotiations have dampened risk appetite, with both the Sensex and Nifty posting weekly declines amid worries over potential fallout on corporate earnings and growth.

summary_points.title: Top Market Triggers: Tariffs, Auto Sales, GST, and Beyond
summary_points.summary: Investors are eyeing a packed calendar of catalysts this week, including updates on U.S. tariffs on India, August auto sales figures, the outcomes of the latest GST Council meeting, foreign fund flows, key global and domestic macroeconomic data releases, and the trajectory of crude oil prices—all of which could dictate the next directional move for equities.

summary_points.title: Consumption Stocks Set to Benefit from GST Cuts
summary_points.summary: According to Geojit’s Vinod Nair, consumption-driven and domestic growth–oriented sectors such as FMCG, durables, discretionary, cement, and infrastructure are well positioned to capitalize on recent GST rate cuts, steady demand, and increased government spending, even as broader market sentiment remains mixed.

summary_points.title: Global Cues Mixed as Asian Markets Diverge
summary_points.summary: Asian equities opened with a mixed bias on Monday, reflecting uneven regional performance, while Wall Street ended lower on Friday as fresh U.S. inflation data and tariff developments undercut investor confidence—highlighting the delicate balance between local economic resilience and broader global headwinds.

summary_points.title: Benchmarks Snap Three‐Day Losing Streak
summary_points.summary: The Sensex and Nifty bucked a three‐day slide on Monday, buoyed by robust GDP data and relief from a favorable court judgment on trade tariffs. The midcap and smallcap indices also saw modest gains as investors rotated back into risk assets following last week’s selloff.

topPerformers.summary: Benefiting from GST rate cuts and resilient consumer demand, FMCG stocks have outperformed peers on steady domestic consumption.
Buoyed by firm demand and higher retail spending, discretionary names have seen relative strength amid mixed broader market trends.
Supported by increased government spending and positive outlook from the GST Council meeting, infrastructure stocks have delivered strong returns.

underperformers.summary: Auto stocks, led by a marginal sales dip at Maruti Suzuki, underperformed amid cautious consumer sentiment and tariff concerns.
The BSE Midcap index lagged, falling 0.41% on continued foreign fund outflows and a tilt toward large-cap IPOs.
Small-cap shares shed 0.29%, pressured by a liquidity drain into mega public offerings and limited institutional buying.

market_drivers.summary: Today’s market action was shaped by a mix of global and domestic factors: Asian peers slid on renewed concerns over US reciprocal tariff rulings and softer US inflation‐linked data, while domestic indices remained cautious ahead of the GST Council meeting where accelerated tax reforms are expected to feature prominently. Institutional flows stayed subdued as investors awaited fresh catalysts, though sectoral shifts—selling pressure in metal and IT stocks—were partly cushioned by steady buying in FMCG and banking names. Currency traders tracked a modest rupee slide alongside a dip in crude futures on lower supply‐risk fears. Specific corporate news, including Bajaj Auto’s 5% jump in August sales driven by strong exports and Lloyds Metals commissioning its new sponge‐iron plant, offered sporadic pockets of optimism amid a broadly risk‐averse tone.
